content.description: Fun warm-up climb or climb for beginners. Lots of orange lichens. Stemming and counter-pressure reliant route.
content.protection: Toprope most often set from large spruce tree or from slinging the large block to the right of the spruce.
content.location: Located in the center of the Falcon Rock Amphitheater. Locate the large white streak that forms a "y". Climb starts at the bottom of the white streak and follows the right arm of the "y" to the top.

content.description:
Follow the bolt line up through block terrain onto the thin sharp face holds and over the top to two anchor bolts with chains. 

 From Fairbanks Area Rock Climbing Guide FO and SJ
content.location: To the right of Chossy Chimney. Start is a bulgy face capped by an overhanging summit block.

content.description: Follow left ward arching crack, full of old rusty pitons, and then up.
content.protection: Sling around horns for top-rope anchor.
content.location: Past "Hole and in the Wall", continue North and lower down until you reach a narrow cleft in the rock.

content.description: "Follows gray nose of the rock on your right just as you leave the cleft." - AAC
content.protection: Sling around horns and fins for top-rope anchor.
content.location: "A line 1/4 inch bolts once scarred this route. Someone in the past put up an aid route but it fell into disrepair. The bolts have been removed and the holes filled in with grout." - AAC

content.description: "On the center left of the North facing wall, look for a flared crack that ends about 10 feet off the ground. First move is harder for short climbers." - AAC
content.protection: "Long Slings around fins and horns make up the dubious top-rope anchor" - AAC
content.location: "On the center left of the North facing wall, look for a flared crack that ends about 10 feet off the ground." - AAC

content.description: Hole in the Wall is named for a 3' diameter hole less than 10 feet from the top. This climb has plenty of sharp holds and a little stemming up to the hole. The crux is passing the hole using a finger crack.
content.protection: Bring enough webbing to tie off to a spruce tree about 15' away.
content.location: Look for a 3' diameter hole near the top. Follow the light colored streak up past the hole. Walk off to the right.

content.description:
"This route is just right of Larry's project and Fat and Fuzzy. This fun sustained sport climb wanders up blocky terrain to a chain anchor that can be reached from the top with a quick belay. Named to help Andy Sterns with his recovery from an accident."

 FO and SJ - Fairbanks Area Rock Climbing Guide
content.location: Second bolted route right of the obvious hole in the wall.

content.description: Fat and Fuzzy climbs a blunt arete right of the bolt line.  Start right of a short dihedral.  The rock was solid, and the climbing was pretty fun, although a bit dirty.  An abundance of good holds leads up the steepening face to the summit.  The only difficulty was at the top where you had to step left because of the rope pull to the anchors.  Not a bad route.
content.protection: Can be top roped from a set of rap anchors above Larry's Project (5.11).  A better option would be to use long slings or webbing to anchor off the spruce tree behind the top (quite a ways back, though).
content.location: Located on the right side of the Hole in the Wall area - just right of a bolted 5.11.

content.description: After going straight up the climb finishes right on the same finish as Thin Grey Line. Top rope bolts on the top of Thin Grey Line can be used to set this climb up.
content.protection: Good protection, top rop bolts with chains on Thin Grey Line.
content.location: In the main ampthiteater move to the left end of the dirt ledge where there is a small alcove. The climb goes up a chimney up from the alcove.

content.description:
The crux is the final moves to the bolts at the top of the climb. 

 From Fairbanks Area Rock Climbing Guide FO and SJ
content.location: This climb starts up the White Grove and then heads left about 15 feet up following a left trending crack feature to a pair of bolts above.

content.description: Falcon Rock is probably the largest single formation on the east side of the highway, and is easily visible from the road.  The rock actually consists of three distinct climbing sections: Refrigerator Crack area (lower left or northwest side of the rock), Peanut Butter area (upper east or northeast side of the rock), and the Hole in the Wall area (the prominent west-facing wall with the twin white streaks).  The longest routes are on the Hole in the Wall Face.
